docs.lead_paragraph: Grace Drake still hopes that someday she will meet Mr. Right and have a family the old-fashioned way. But as the program director of a fertility clinic in Austin, Tex., Ms. Drake, 35, sees women every day who are in their 30's and 40's and want desperately to have children but cannot. So she decided to take out some insurance: She froze her eggs.

headline.main: For Women Worried About Fertility, Egg Bank Is a New Option

docs.abstract: Extend Fertility, company that offers egg freezing to women wanting to preserve ability to have children later in life, now has clinics in Los Angeles, San Francisco, Dallas and New York; only around 100 babies worldwide have been born using frozen eggs; Christy Jones, Harvard University MBA and founder of company, acknowledges that process is expensive, but holds that all fertility-related procedures have high price tag; process of freezing eggs, which requires dehydration to prevent damaging ice crystals from forming, described; American Society for Reproductive Medicine warns that freezing eggs should not be used as way for older women to have babies, but recognizes that technology is advancing at rapid pace; photos (M)
docs.snippet: For single women who want children, egg freezing may be a reproductive insurance policy.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE KNOW-IT-ALL One Man's Humble Quest to Become the Smartest Person in the World By A.J. Jacobs 386 pages. Simon & Schuster. $25. ALPHABETICAL The order in which A.J. Jacobs has arranged the chapters of his book ''The Know-It-All.'' Each chapter is devoted to an individual letter of the alphabet, except for the closing chapter. It lumps X, Y and Z together. X, Y and Z are used to this.
docs.abstract: Janet Maslin reviews book The Know-It-All: One Man's Humble Quest to Become the Smartest Person in the World by A J Jacobs; photo (M)
docs.snippet: In its own joking way, A. J. Jacobs's book about his reading of the Britannica encyclopedia seeks a working definition of what it means to be smart.

docs.lead_paragraph: Women's Health Connecticut, an association of 150 of the state's obstetricians and gynecologists, announced last week that its members had decided not to assess a planned $500 surcharge to patients for delivering babies. Nancy Bernstein, the president and chief officer of Women's Health Connecticut, said the doctors had originally planned to begin the surcharge on Sept. 1 to offset the high cost of malpractice insurance, if the State Legislature did not pass tort reform.

headline.main: OB-Gyns Drop Efforts For a Delivery Surcharge

docs.abstract: Women's Health Connecticut, association of 150 obstetricians and gynecologists, decides against assessing planned $500 surcharge on patients for delivering babies to offset high cost of malpractice insurance (S)
docs.snippet: Women's Health Connecticut, an association of 150 of the state's obstetricians and gynecologists, announced last week that its members had decided not to assess a planned $500 surcharge to patients for delivering babies.    Nancy Bernstein, the...

docs.lead_paragraph: RACHEL loves Mike. Mike loves Rachel. Mike also loves Carol and is trying to seduce Alice. Rachel punched Mike and wept hysterically when she saw him flirt with Alice, which was a little hypocritical since she is also having an affair with Carol. Surprisingly, Ted, a child adopted by Rachel and Mike, seems to take all this in stride. Sims 2, a much enhanced version of the life-simulation game from Maxis, is the video-game answer to reality television shows like ''The Real World'' and ''Big Brother.'' Like these shows, Sims 2 allows the lives of its characters to unfold in moments of chaos and carnality. But unlike television, in which the audience is confined to the role of passive viewer, the game puts you into the action in the role of a god. And not a distant, magnanimous god, but one of those petty Roman gods who amuse themselves by toying with people.
docs.abstract: Charles Herold Game Theory column reviews Sims 2; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Sims 2, a sequel to one of the most successful video games ever, once again seems like a little girl's dream of a dollhouse come to life - this time in 3-D.

docs.lead_paragraph: With two sets of twins already, Eric and Elizabeth Hayes of Marlboro decided they wanted another baby. They got six. Ms. Hayes delivered sextuplets early on Tuesday at Monmouth Medical Center. The pregnancy was 32 weeks along, about six weeks from a normal single delivery but well beyond the stage at which many multiple births occur, doctors said. The newborns are three girls and three boys, ranging from 3 pounds 9 ounces to 4 pounds 10 ounces. All but one needed help breathing through oxygen tubes in their noses, but they are in good health. Ms. Hayes underwent fertility treatments, including drugs, to help her conceive.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Long Branch: Sextuplets Born Prematurely

docs.abstract: Elizabeth Hayes of Marlboro, NJ, delivers sextuplets about six weeks before they are due (S)
docs.snippet: With two sets of twins already, Eric and Elizabeth Hayes of Marlboro decided they wanted another baby. They got six. Ms. Hayes delivered sextuplets early on Tuesday at Monmouth Medical Center. The pregnancy was 32 weeks along, about six weeks from a...

headline.main: Is Chivalry Dead? Or Is It Underground?

docs.lead_paragraph: Tom Coburn, a family doctor and Republican Senate candidate, is caught in a controversy over claims that he sterilized a 20-year-old patient without proper consent and defrauded the government by withholding information about the procedure. ''I saved the woman's life,'' Dr. Coburn, a former congressman, said in an interview Tuesday, in which he dismissed the fraud accusation. But his Democratic opponent, Representative Brad Carson, said that the charges were serious and that Dr. Coburn should answer them.

headline.main: Old Suit Roils Senate Race In Oklahoma

docs.abstract: Tom Coburn, family doctor and Republican candidate for US Senate in Oklahoma, is caught in controversy over claims that he sterilized 20-year-old patient without proper consent and defrauded government by withholding information about procedure; he declares, 'I saved the woman's life'; his Democratic opponent, Rep Brad Carson, contends charges are serious and that Coburn should answer them; claim stems from 13-year-old malpractice suit that was dismissed when patient failed to show up for court; Coburn photo (S)
